results.title: The Poseidon adventure
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Irwin Allen and Ronald Neame
results.brief_description: One of the finest disaster/adventure movies of the 1970s, “The Poseidon adventure” is set on an ocean liner, capsized by a ninety-foot tidal wave one New Year’s Eve. With the boat upside down in the water, a dozen survivors make a desperate dash for the bottom of the boat - their only way out. The camaraderie of the group is tested as they face constant danger of flooding and explosions, struggling through six levels of the boat, headed for the bowels of the ship. Aside from impressive special effects, the film essentially boils down to a battle of wills between two rival leaders of the posse - a no-nonsense reverend (Gene Hackman) and a hothead detective, Mike Rogo (Ernest Borgnine). “The Poseidon adventure” was nominated for seven Academy awards, and won two, for Best Song and a Special Achievement Award for visual effects. Adapted from the novel by Paul Gallico.

results.title: The Ploughman's lunch
results.creator_credit: Greenpoint Films, Simon Relph, Ann Scott and Richard Eyre
results.brief_description: Reporter James Penfield makes his money rearranging the facts, a talent he ruthlessly exploits in his friendship and love affairs. A political drama set against the backdrop of the Falkland’s crisis, the film takes a wry look at the Government’s attempt to justify the war. Set in the heartland of bourgeois England among media creators and academics, the personal, political and historical deceit of Thatcher’s Britain is ruthlessly exposed. Stars Jonathan Pryce and Tim Curry and features an astonishing climax as the crew and cast filmed undercover during the Conservative Party Conference.

results.title: The Player
results.creator_credit: Spelling International, Avenue Pictures, David Brown, Michael Tolkin, Nick Wechsler and Robert Altman
results.brief_description: A sharp critique of Hollywood greed and power, director Robert Altman hits nails on heads as this Faustian black comedy unfolds on the screen. This cynical story begins with Griffin Mill (Tim Robbins), a smarmy young studio executive who is being threatened by a disgruntled and previously rejected screenwriter. Griffin decides to take the law into his own hands and accidentally kills the writer. Will he get away with it? Whoopi Goldberg is hilarious as the unconventional detective investigating the murder, Greta Scacchi is strange and seductive as the dead writer’s girlfriend and Peter Gallagher is truly slimy as the rising young star executive. The film also includes cameo appearances from sixty-five of Hollywood’s biggest names.

results.title: The Pirate
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Arthur Freed and Vincente Minnelli
results.brief_description: Set in the West Indies, a young Manuela (Judy Garland) is told by her aunt Inez that arrangements are being made for her to wed the mysterious new mayor of the town, Don Pedro Vargas (Walter Slezak). Manuela is crushed, as it signals an end to her fantasies of being swept off her feet by the legend of the romantic, yet notorious pirate - Macoco. Being a dutiful surrogate daughter to the aunt and uncle who have been like parents to her, Manuel agrees to the marriage, and they soon take a short trip to the Caribbean island of San Sebastian. As fate will have it, a magician and his troupe arrive in San Sebastian at the same time, ready to perform for the locals. The magician is taken by Manuela’s beauty, and after a failed attempt to seduce her, convinces her to come along to the show. The magician tries to win Manuela’s heart by impersonating the man of her dreams, the pirate Macoco, and during his performance hypnotises then kisses her. Now totally smitten, the “pirate” Serafin follows Manuela home to try and convince her to run away with him, only to be discovered by Don Pedro Vargas, who is recognised by the magician as being the “real” Macoco. Based on the play of the same name by S. N. Behrman, as produced by The Playwrights Producing Company and The Theatre Guild. Cast also includes Gladys Cooper and Reginald Owen. Songs by Cole Porter.

results.title: The Pillow book
results.creator_credit: Channel 4 Films, Delux Productions, Studio Canal Plus, Kees Kasander and Peter Greenaway
results.brief_description: An erotic fantasy that combines two limitless fascinations - flesh and literatures. Nagiko (Vivian Wu) flees an unhappy marriage in her native Japan to work as a model in Hong Kong. Nagiko holds treasured childhood memories of the annual ritual of her calligrapher father (Ken Ogata) gently painting a traditional birthday greeting on her face. In Hong Kong she takes a string of lovers, whom she values more for their calligraphy than their sexual skills, asking them to write on her body. An English lover (Ewan McGregor) suggests she starts writing herself, using her lovers as papers. However, his plan to get her writing published backfires with tragic consequences. Some sections in Japanese with English sub-titles.

results.title: The Picture Show Man
results.creator_credit: Limelight Productions, Joan Long and John Power
results.brief_description: Maurice Pym is a travelling cinema operator in the 1920’s who, with his son Larry and his dapper pianist Freddie, covers the back roads of northern New South Wales. The film follows their adventures and their rivalry with a brash American rival who intrudes into their territory and threatens to steal their livelihood. Based on the memoirs of Lyle Penn, the film nostalgically depicts a past age, and the effect of new technologies on the cinema industry. Cast includes Rod Taylor, John Meillon and Jeanie Drynan.

results.title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Pandro S. Berman and Albert Lewin
results.brief_description: The picture of Dorian Gray is a superb film based on Oscar Wilde’s novel about a young man who wishes that his portrait could age while he remains youthful. The portrait does grow old, showing not only Dorian Gray’s age but also the sins and aberrations of his wicked life. Dorian remains handsome, young and seemingly uncorrupted by his own decadence. Stars George Sanders, Hurd Hatfield, Donna Reed, Angela Lansbury and Peter Lawford.

results.title: The Piano teacher = La Pianiste [DVD] (E)
results.creator_credit: MK2 Productions, Les Films Alain Sarde, Wega Film, Arte France, Marin Karmitz, Alain Sarde, Veit Heiduschka and Michael Haneke
results.brief_description: Erika Kohut (Isabelle Huppert) is a repressed middle-aged classical piano teacher in Vienna who lives with her demanding, manipulative mother (Annie Girardot). Erika presents a cool, detached aristocratic demeanor to her students and to the world. But she also leads a masochistic private life: she searches for anonymous sex in pornographic theatres, which in turn leads her to self-destructive acts of self-mutilation to assuage her guilt. When a handsome young music student, Walter (Benoit Magimel), attempts to seduce Erika, his forthright masculinity and her own masochistic desires create an untenable situation for the piano teacher. Erika begins to force her mother to acknowledge the incestuous underpinnings of their destructive relationship and she forces Walter to confront a damaged femininity for which he is unprepared. Michael Haneke’s films have all been defined by a cold detached observation of social breakdown. “The Piano teacher”, based on Elfriede Jelinek’s novel, is a powerful and deeply disturbing film. Huppert’s performance is central to the film’s success. It is a performance of deep courage and she creates one of screen history’s most devastating and unrelenting portrayals of feminine masochism. But this is not only a film about individual sexual dysfunction. For Haneke, Erika’s repression and self-disgust is firmly connected to her passion for the rigours and classicism of European music. The Viennese Conservatory in which she teaches becomes a symbol of highly controlled, repressive bourgeois and aristocratic culture, a culture which demands the inhuman vanquishing of contradiction and emotion. This is a bleakly unsettling film which suggests that built into the very foundations of Western “high art” is an oppressive, vigilant surveillance and repression of excess and desire. Obviously, and not unsurprisingly with its Viennese setting, the film shares a deeply Freudian pessimism about the future of culture. This is not an easy film to watch and it contains extremely disturbing images of sexual self-abuse. It is nevertheless a consistent and unforgettable investigation of Western culture at a point of spiritual collapse. And the film is unimaginable without Huppert whose performance allows us to both understand individual suffering and the wider social and political analogies that Haneke wants to draw through her character. Huppert won the Best Actress Award and Magimel won the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival for their performances. The DVD interviews with Haneke and Jelinek are outstanding as is the commentary by Huppert.

results.title: The Philadelphia story (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Joseph L Mankiewicz and George Cukor
results.brief_description: A wealthy society girl, who is about to marry for the second time, finds she still loves her first husband. This witty and sophisticated romantic comedy features a sparkling screenplay, great performances and has a well-deserved reputation as a Hollywood “screwball” classic. With Katherine Hepburn, Cary Grant and James Stewart. Based on a play by Philip Barry and the inspiration for the musical “High Society”.
